datafield.subfield: Most items are dated between 1621 and 1623.
Use: Unrestricted, for either reading room or classroom use

Contains two tracts by Thomas Scott (1580?-1626), Vox Populi News from Spayne (published 1626) and Vox spiritus or Sir Walter Rawleighes ghoste (published 1620) concerning the Spanish ambassador to England, Diego Sarmiento de AcunÌ³a, Conde de Gondomar (1567-1626); poems; epitaphs; copies of several letters concerning the King, George Abbott the Archbishop of Canterbury (1562-1633), the Lord Keeper, and parliamentary and legal matters, including the examination of the Earl of Southampton, and the 1613 divorce proceedings between Lady Frances Howard (1593-1632) and Robert Devereux, Earl of Essex (1591-1646).
Farmer, Norman K. Jr., Robert Herrick's Commonplace Book? Some Observations and Questions. PBSA, 66 (1972), 21-34.
Norman K. Farmer, Robert Herrick's Commonplace Book? Some Observations and Questions, Papers of the Bibliographical Society of America 66/1 (1972): 21-34.

MS 3327, Container 79: Offered by London booksellers Puttick & Simpson, 30 August 1849, no. 158; acquired by Sir Thomas Phillipps (1792-1872), no. 12341*; unidentified dealers' marks on the front pastedown: a 57.1229 and 625 F2; acquired by the Ransom Center in 1964 (R2722) from the House of El Dieff. DIDB record: 12872. Binding: Half brown tanned calfskin with dark blue cloth over paper boards. Straight caps, smooth spine on hollow tube, edges cut before sewing. No decoration on covers; blind-tooled roll across spine (six panels), gold-tooled red goatskin spine title label. No endbands. Sewn on three (flattened?) cords, laced on boards. Endleaf components: front tipped fold off-white handmade laid paper making pastedown, free endleaf, and text blank; back same. (England, 1847 (see binder s ticket inside front cover))
Medieval and Early Modern Manuscripts Collection
